rdf:Description.dct:title: More Than Just Acetates: PhI(OAc)2 Enables C–H Halogenation of Arenes
rdf:Description.dct:creator: Sarah E. Wengryniuk
rdf:Description.cp:licenseLine: This article is made available under the Elsevier license.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: C–H Halogenation Platform for Both Arenes and (Hetero)arenes with Novel Non-symmetrical Iodanes Generated In Situ from PhI(OAc)2

ja:head.ce:title: More Than Just Acetates: PhI(OAc)2 Enables C–H Halogenation of Arenes

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, Temple University, 1901 North 13th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19122, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this issue of Chem, Nagib and co-workers report an operationally simple approach for direct C–H halogenation of arenes and (hetero)arenes through in situ activation of commercially available PhI(OAc)2. The resulting non-symmetrical iodanes offer chemists new tools for the mild halogenation of arene scaffolds with exquisite selectivity and tunability.

In this issue of Chem, Nagib and co-workers report an operationally simple approach for direct C–H halogenation of arenes and (hetero)arenes through in situ activation of commercially available PhI(OAc)2. The resulting non-symmetrical iodanes offer chemists new tools for the mild halogenation of arene scaffolds with exquisite selectivity and tunability.

ce:section.ce:para: Novel approaches to the functionalization of arenes and (hetero)arenes are one of the most active areas of research in modern synthetic chemistry. In particular, the synthesis of halogenated arenes is of immense interest because these motifs are ubiquitous in natural products, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials. In addition to being able to tune physical properties and bioactivity, halogens and (pseudo)halogens also serve as versatile functional handles for derivatization, most commonly via cross couplings. Given their ubiquity and importance, it is perhaps surprising that most methods for their installation still rely on old reagents that suffer from either harsh reaction conditions or a lack of sufficient reactivity and therefore fail to offer general solutions to the modern synthetic chemist. Advances in transition-metal C–H activation have produced elegant approaches,1 but these lack generality. With the exception of Palau’chlor, which is primarily applicable to electron-rich arenes and (hetero)arenes,2 there has been very limited progress in the development of novel halogenating reagents. As such, a general solution to the direct C–H halogenation of both arenes and (hetero)arenes remains an unmet synthetic challenge.

Hypervalent iodine reagents have seen a resurgence of interest in the last 20 years as researchers have sought out cost-effective, non-toxic, mild alternatives to transition metals.3 In particular, λ3-iodanes have emerged as incredibly versatile organic oxidants and group-transfer reagents. As part of their research program directed toward hypervalent-iodine-mediated C–H functionalization, the Nagib laboratory at The Ohio State University set out to devise a mild, cost-effective, and versatile solution to arene and (hetero)arene C–H halogenation. In this issue of Chem, Nagib and co-workers report on the realization of this goal with a suite of in situ activation strategies that enable the use of bench-stable, commercially available (bisacetoxyiodo)benzene (PhI(OAc)2) as a precursor to highly reactive, non-symmetric λ3-iodane species (Scheme 1).4 These non-symmetrical iodanes facilitate the incorporation of halogens and (pseudo)halogens onto electron-rich arenes as well as electron-poor (hetero)arenes with excellent chemoselectivity and predictable site selectivity. The unusually broad scope and selectivity are a result of two divergent mechanisms depending on the substrate class, resulting in a single reaction platform where reactivity can be tuned simply through changing the activator.

Although isolable, non-symmetrical iodanes such as Koser’s reagent (PhI(OH)OTs) and cyclic benziodoxolone derivatives (e.g., IBA–Cl and IBA–N3) are well established, reports of novel, acyclic, non-symmetrical iodanes are scarce, most likely because of challenges with their controlled synthesis and resulting instability. It has, however, been found that the reactivity of λ3-iodanes can be modulated by treatment with either Brønsted or Lewis acids, and Shafir and co-workers recently provided spectroscopic evidence of a resulting desymmetrized iodonium-like species in these systems.5 Inspired by these findings, the authors proposed that treatment of commercially available PhI(OAc)2 with an appropriate Brønsted or Lewis acid would lead to a highly reactive non-symmetrical iodane and that this species could then facilitate halogenation through two possible mechanisms (Scheme 1). In the case of electron-rich arenes, initial oxidation to give a radical cation would be followed by nucleophilic attack with an anion to give para-selective functionalization. Conversely, electron-deficient (hetero)arenes could undergo functionalization by attack on a highly electrophilic iodonium species generated upon dissociation of one of the acetate ligands, giving rise to halogen incorporation at the most nucleophilic position.

Overall, their approach proved highly successful, and the ability of this reagent system to undergo two divergent reaction manifolds gives rise to one of the broadest scopes for a single halogenation platform to date. Simple in situ treatment of PhI(OAc)2 with various Brønsted acids in 1,2-dichloroethane at 50°C leads to clean incorporation of their nucleophilic counteranions (Cl−, Br−, and −OSO2R) onto the para-position of N-Piv-o-toluidine in excellent yield. Given that chlorine is the most versatile of the halogens, serving as both a functional handle and a ubiquitous motif medicinal agent, chlorination was chosen for further scope studies and found to be quite general and tolerant of a broad range of functionality. When addressing (hetero)arene halogenation, Brønsted acids were not suitable activators as they led to protonation and thus deactivation of the heterocycle for electrophilic attack on the iodonium. However, changing the activator to an acyl chloride led to clean chlorination of a wide range of medicinally relevant (hetero)arenes. Particularly noteworthy is the efficiency of this method for the chlorination of quinolines and isoquinolines, substrates unreactive with common existing chlorinating agents, including Palau’chlor, IBA-Cl, and N-chlorosuccinimide. Finally, their approach was found to be sufficiently mild and selective to be used in late-stage derivatizations of several complex molecules. Particularly impressive is the chlorination of lidocaine, which possesses a free tertiary amine that is highly sensitive to oxidation.

By utilizing complimentary activating systems for the two substrate classes, the authors were able to demonstrate the chemoselective halogenation of either an arene or a (hetero)arene within a single reaction simply by proper selection of the activator. One can imagine the utility of this feature for iterative functionalizations, such as installing –Cl followed by –Br or –OSO2R onto a complex molecule with pinpoint precision.

Although the proposed non-symmetrical iodanes are highly reactive and thus not isolable, the authors provide several key control experiments as well as spectroscopic evidence to support their formation. Alternative pathways invoking the formation of either a mixed diaryliodonium salt or salts with two heterocyclic nitrogen ligands on the central iodine, analogous to Weiss’ reagents,6 were both excluded. 1H-NMR spectroscopic studies indicate the generation of a new species that is different from both PhI(OAc)2 and PhICl2. Notably the same iodane is generated upon activation with either HCl or AcCl, indicating that a single common species is responsible for halogenation of both arenes or (hetero)arenes.

With any methodology, the ability to predict reactivity and selectivity on complex scaffolds beyond those described in the initial report is paramount. In this case, the authors offer up two techniques for predicting the site selectivity of halogenation. For (hetero)arenes proceeding through simple electrophilic halogenation, mapping of electron densities accurately identifies the site of functionalization as that with the greatest amount of partial negative charge. In contrast, for electron-rich arenes, which proceed via an intermediate radical cation, the authors employed Fukui values, which account for both the partial charges of atoms in the parent molecule and the centers of greatest electron loss upon oxidation. This approach was particularly powerful in predicting the selectivity in several complex molecules that had numerous potential reactive sites.

In summary, Nagib and co-workers have developed a powerful new platform for arene C–H halogenation by using simple in situ activation of commercially available PhI(OAc)2. Most impressively, this single approach is capable of functionalizing both electron-rich arenes and (hetero)arenes by performing through two distinct mechanistic pathways. By offering a powerful combination of both high reactivity and mild reaction conditions, this approach addresses many of the shortcomings of existing halogenation reagents. By demonstrating the accessibility and utility of the in-situ-formed non-symmetrical iodanes, the authors also provide a significant advance in the development of λ3-iodane reagents with heterogeneous ligand composition.
